column2: As she was shaking the crumbs from her lap, she heard voices and pounding, splashing hoofs from up the trail.

column2: Fresh and tender, the light of the mild spring afternoon caressed the little abandoned clearing in the wilderness.
column3: Fresh and tender, the light of the mild spring afternoon caressed the little abandoned clearing in the wilderness.

column2: At the back of the clearing, beneath a solitary white birch tree just bursting into green, stood a squatter's log cabin, long deserted, its door and window gone, its roof of poles and bark half fallen in.
column3: At the back of the clearing, beneath a solitary white birch tree just bursting into green, stood a squatter's log cabin, long deserted, its door and window gone, its roof of poles and bark half fallen in.

column2: Past the foot of the clearing, with dancing sparkle and a crisp, musical clamor, ran a shallow stream some dozen yards in width, its clear waters amber-tawny from the far-off cedar-swamps in which it took its rise.
column3: Past the foot of the clearing, with dancing sparkle and a crisp, musical clamor, ran a shallow stream some dozen yards in width, its clear waters amber tawny from the far off cedar swamps in which it took its rise.

column2: Along one side came the deeply rutted backwoods road, skirting the clearing and making its precarious way across the stream by a rude bridge not lightly to be ventured after dark.
column3: Along one side came the deeply rutted backwoods road, skirting the clearing and making its precarious way across the stream by a rude bridge not lightly to be ventured after dark.

column2: Over all the face of the lonely backwoods world was washed the high, thin green of the New Brunswick May-time, under a sky of crystal cobalt dotted with dense white fleeces.
column3: Over all the face of the lonely backwoods world was washed the high, thin green of the New Brunswick May time, under a sky of crystal cobalt dotted with dense white fleeces.

column2: Before the ruined cabin stood a light wagon, its wheels and polished body bespattered with mud.
column3: Before the ruined cabin stood a light wagon, its wheels and polished body bespattered with mud.

column2: In the open back of the wagon, thrust well under the seat to be in the shade, lay a large wicker fishing-basket, with a tuft of grass sticking out through the square hole in the cover. Some ten or a dozen paces distant, tethered beneath the birch tree, a sorrel horse munched the last remnants of a bundle of hay, and whisked his long tail industriously to keep off the flies.

column2: From behind a corner of the ruined cabin peered craftily a red fox.
column3: From behind a corner of the ruined cabin peered craftily a red fox.

column2: He eyed the wagon, he eyed the horse beneath the birch tree, he scrutinized the whole clearing, the road, and the open stretch of the stream.
column3: He eyed the wagon, he eyed the horse beneath the birch tree, he scrutinized the whole clearing, the road, and the open stretch of the stream.

column2: Then his narrowed, searching gaze returned to the wagon and to the fat basket in the back of the wagon.
column3: Then his narrowed, searching gaze returned to the wagon and to the fat basket in the back of the wagon.

column2: At length he stepped forth mincingly into full view, trotted up, and sniffed inquisitively.
column3: At length he stepped forth mincingly into full view, trotted up, and sniffed inquisitively.

column2: As if in doubt, he raised himself on his hind legs, with his fore-paws on the tire of the nearest wheel, and took a long, satisfying sniff.
column3: As if in doubt, he raised himself on his hind legs, with his fore paws on the tire of the nearest wheel, and took a long, satisfying sniff.

column2: Yes, undoubtedly there were fish in the basket, fresh fish--trout, in fact.

column3: He settled himself back upon his haunches to spring into the wagon.

column2: At this season the trout--fine, vivid fish, of good pan size--were lying in the open, dancing runs and about the tails of the rapids; and they were rising freely to almost any bright fly, though with a preference for a red hackle.

column2: They had emptied all their catch into one basket, stowed the basket under the wagon seat, then started off again to fish the finer reaches of the stream, with its wide pools and long, sunlit rapids, below the bridge. column2: Soon after the departure of the over-crafty fox, a backwoods tramp came by, with a ragged little bundle slung from the stick on his shoulder. His eyes lighted up at sight of the unguarded wagon from town, and he understood the situation at a glance.
column3: Soon after the departure of the over crafty fox, a backwoods tramp came by, with a ragged little bundle slung from the stick on his shoulder. His eyes lighted up at sight of the unguarded wagon from town, and he understood the situation at a glance.

column3: He hurriedly devoured about half the contents of the lunch basket, transferred the rest to his dirty bundle, and with huge satisfaction lighted a half burned cigar which one of the fishermen had left lying on a log. Next he investigated the fishing basket.

column3: Half a dozen of the finest fish he took out and strung upon a forked twig.

column2: Puffing his cigar butt in high good humor, he went over and made friends with the horse, feeding it with a few handfuls of fresh grass. The horse, feeling rather lonely, neighed after him as he disappeared.

column2: He could not imagine a fiery-tempered personage like the mink tamely submitting to the rape of his banquet.
column3: He could not imagine a fiery tempered personage like the mink tamely submitting to the rape of his banquet.

column2: He felt sure that in the next second or two a snaky black shape, all teeth and springs and venom, would dart from the basket and be at his throat. He was ready for it, but he was not hankering after it.
column3: He felt sure that in the next second or two a snaky black shape, all teeth and springs and venom, would dart from the basket and be at his throat. He was ready for it, but he was not hankering after it.

column2: Meanwhile, there behind the basket lid, the mink was raging irresolutely.
column3: Meanwhile, there behind the basket lid, the mink was raging irresolutely.

column2: It galled him to the marrow to watch his big, arrogant, bush-tailed rival complacently gulping down those fine fat trout. But--well, he had himself already eaten one of the trout and a good part of another.
column3: It galled him to the marrow to watch his big, arrogant, bush tailed rival complacently gulping down those fine fat trout. But-well, he had himself already eaten one of the trout and a good part of another.

column2: His hunger was blunted.
column3: His hunger was blunted.

column2: He could rage within reason, and his reason admonished him to keep out of this fight if it could be managed. He knew the whipcord muscle underlying that soft red fur, the deadly grip of those long, narrow jaws.
column3: He could rage within reason, and his reason admonished him to keep out of this fight if it could be managed. He knew the whipcord muscle underlying that soft red fur, the deadly grip of those long, narrow jaws.

column2: There is no peace counsellor like a contented belly.
column3: There is no peace counsellor like a contented belly.

column2: So he snarled softly to himself and waited.
column3: So he snarled softly to himself and waited.

column2: The fox, having swallowed as much as he could hold, stood up, stretched himself, and licked his chaps.
column3: The fox, having swallowed as much as he could hold, stood up, stretched himself, and licked his chaps.

column2: The look which he kept upon the basket was no less vigilant than before, but there was now a tinge of scorn in it.
column3: The look which he kept upon the basket was no less vigilant than before, but there was now a tinge of scorn in it.

column2: There were still some trout left, but he wanted to get away.
column3: There were still some trout left, but he wanted to get away.

column2: He snatched up the two biggest fish in his jaws and trotted off with them to the woods, glancing back over his shoulder as he went.
column3: He snatched up the two biggest fish in his jaws and trotted off with them to the woods, glancing back over his shoulder as he went.

column2: Before he had gained the cover of the fir trees, the mink glided forth, planted his forepaws on the remaining fish, and stood staring after him in an attitude of challenge.
column3: Before he had gained the cover of the fir trees, the mink glided forth, planted his forepaws on the remaining fish, and stood staring after him in an attitude of challenge.

column2: Had the fox returned, the mink would now have fought.
column3: Had the fox returned, the mink would now have fought.

column2: But the fox had no thought of returning.
column3: But the fox had no thought of returning.

column2: There was nothing to fight about.
column3: There was nothing to fight about.

column2: He had got what he wanted.
column3: He had got what he wanted.

column2: He had no rooted objection to the mink having what was left.
column3: He had no rooted objection to the mink having what was left.

column2: He trotted away nonchalantly toward his burrow under the roots of an old birch tree on the hill.
column3: He trotted away nonchalantly toward his burrow under the roots of an old birch tree on the hill.

column2: The mink stuffed himself till he could not get another mouthful down. There were still a couple of trout untouched.
column3: The mink stuffed himself till he could not get another mouthful down. There were still a couple of trout untouched.

column2: He eyed them regretfully, but he had not the fox's wit or providence to carry them off and hide them for future use.
column3: He eyed them regretfully, but he had not the fox's wit or providence to carry them off and hide them for future use.

column2: He left them, therefore, with a collection of neatly severed heads and tails, to mock the fishermen when they should return at sunset.
column3: He left them, therefore, with a collection of neatly severed heads and tails, to mock the fishermen when they should return at sunset.

column2: He was feeling very drowsy.
column3: He was feeling very drowsy.

column2: At a deliberate pace, quite unlike his usual eager and darting movements, he made off down the clearing toward the water.
column3: At a deliberate pace, quite unlike his usual eager and darting movements, he made off down the clearing toward the water.

column2: Beneath the bank was an old musquash hole which he was well acquainted with.
column3: Beneath the bank was an old musquash hole which he was well acquainted with.

column2: Only the other day, indeed, he had cleared out its inhabitants, devouring their litter of young.
column3: Only the other day, indeed, he had cleared out its inhabitants, devouring their litter of young.

column2: He crawled into the hole, curled up on the soft, dead grass of the devastated nest, and cosily went to sleep.
column3: He crawled into the hole, curled up on the soft, dead grass of the devastated nest, and cosily went to sleep.
